Risk Management Program (RMP) PCS Phosphate - Aurora, NC



This Executive Summary for the Risk Management Program conforms to Sections 68.155 through

68.185. Referenced documents, such as the Comprehensive Emergency Management Plan, Process Safety Management Plan, Spill Prevention, Containment and Countermeasures (SPCC) and Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (OPA 90) plans are maintained at the facility and are available for inspection by authorized individuals.



  

  Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Safety of our people and protection of the environment are core values at Aurora. We are committed to creating a culture that takes safety seriously and personally. Nothing is more important to the company than returning our people home safely at the end of each day. We believe that all injuries are preventable.  We believe it is the responsibility of each and every employee to prevent injuries, not only to themselves, but to their co-workers. Each of us has a responsibility to act at all times in a safe manner.  We are committed to being the safety leader in our industry. Safety awareness on the part of each and every employee is essential to achieve our stated objectives.



PCS Aurora strives to achieve no damage to the environment at all of our operations. Our role as environmental stewards is important. We work every day to protect the land, water, and air surrounding our facility.  The relationships we have with our neighbors and surrounding communities are an important part of what we work so hard to build and maintain. PCS provides a safe environment for all employees, contractors, visitors and neighbors. Operations of the facility are designed so as not to adversely affect the environment of the surrounding area during emergency situations or normal operating periods.



It is the emergency response policy of the PCS Aurora facility to immediately notify the National Response Center, State LEPC and County LEPC of an accidental release of anhydrous am

monia in excess of 100 pounds, so that the public can be notified in a timely manner if necessary.  PCS employees will mitigate, contain the release, and provide emergency medical treatment for any injured onsite personnel.





  Description of the Facility



The PCS facility in Aurora, NC covers 12,000 acres and sits along the Pamlico River. The Pamlico River empties into the Pamlico Sound, ten miles downstream of the facility. The Aurora facility is the world's largest vertically integrated fertilizer enterprise. Operations include a phosphate mine, ore refining facilities, sulfuric acid and phosphoric acid plants, fertilizer materials plants, purified phosphoric acid plants and hydrogen fluoride production.



The principal raw materials used at the Aurora site are phosphate rock, sulfur and ammonia. Phosphate ore is mined in adjacent open pit mines and transported via water slurry in enclosed pipes to the mineral processing area. Elemental sulfur is transported in railcars and barges to the facility where it is used to produce sulfuric acid, which in turn is used to produce phosphoric acid. The phosphoric acid is used as the feedstock to produce solid or liquid fertilizers. Ammonia, in anhydrous form, is transported to the plant in railcars or trucks where it is used to make solid and liquid fertilizers by reacting with phosphoric acid.  The anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the railcars and trucks to storage containers in a specially designed and built facility that incorporates essential safety features.



 The AHF production produces liquid AHF that will be stored in two of three storage tanks.   Each tank has a maximum capacity of 71,300 gal and an operating capacity of 57,040 gal.  One tank is kept empty and available in the event one of the primary tanks develops a leak and the inventory needs to be transferred to the empty tank.  The three storage tanks are located within a larger containment tank.  The temperature of the AHF in the storage tanks i

s controlled by a circulating cooler loop to maintain the temperature within the range of 15 to 45?F.  The storage tanks and containment tank are vented to a scrubber to minimize potential releases of HF to the atmosphere.



The AHF in the storage tanks is pumped into railcars for subsequent staging onsite prior to being shipped offsite.  The railcars are loaded in an enclosure that is adjacent to the containment tank.  Each railcar has a maximum capacity of 21,850 gal and a maximum loaded capacity of 161,690 lb of AHF.  The loaded railcars are moved to an onsite staging area prior to being shipped offsite. 



PCS Phosphate Aurora facility employs approximately 885 people and because of its isolated location, the facility has its own medical facilities, fire response team, hazardous materials response team, rescue team and medical response team.





  General Accidental Release Prevention Program



The PCS Aurora facility is in full compliance with the OSHA PSM rule. Additionally, the use of Safety and Operating Procedures provide a system to avert accidental releases by focusing on specific components of each RMP/PSM regulated substance. Safety and operating procedure manuals consist of safety and operating procedures, uniquely designed for specific job tasks associated with RMP/PSM regulated substances.  These manuals are reviewed annually and revised as necessary to address any changes.  



Ammonia: Every inbound anhydrous ammonia shipment receives detailed inspections.  Employees and contractors are trained regularly to ensure proficiency in phases of the operation. The ammonia handling system is constructed of stainless steel in many areas. Operating control systems, video surveillance, and ammonia detection systems provide opportunity for quick response to changes in operating conditions in the railcar and truck unloading areas and ammonia storage area. Emergency shut off valves and a water deluge system aid in mitigation if a release occurs.



Anhydrous

Hydrogen Fluoride: Employees are trained regularly to ensure proficiency in phases of the operation.  Operating control systems, video surveillance, and HF detection systems provide the opportunity for quick response to any changes in operating conditions in the plants and at the railcar loading area. The railcars are loaded within an enclosed building equipped with HF detection and deluge showers.  The plant storage tanks for AHF are located inside of a secondary containment tank.  HF containing vessels within the plants are equipped with chilled water-cooling jackets to keep stored HF at a stable temperature.  Emergency shut off valves and a water deluge system aid in mitigation if a release occurs.



Preventive maintenance programs, testing, calibrations, routine maintenance, inspections, replacement of equipment as necessary, and training of personnel all contribute to the prevention of a release.  A work order system is in place to formally report deficiencies and track them until rectified.





  Five Year Accident History



The PCS Aurora facility has had no accidents in the past 5 years that is required to be reported in the RMP.





  Emergency Response Program



The PCS Aurora facility has developed a Comprehensive Emergency Management Plan (CEMP) designed to address prevention, preparation, response, and recovery from a wide variety of potential emergencies to include an accidental release of a regulated substance at the facility. The facility, its employees, and business operations are susceptible to emergencies, such as natural disasters, severe weather and man-made hazards.  The CEMP, in conjunction with the Risk Management Program and OSHAs Process Safety Management for Highly Hazardous Chemicals Program (PSM), aid in managing potential emergency situations.



The facility maintains an aggressive training program for all members of its four emergency response teams (medical, hazardous materials, technical rescue and fire), its emergency managem

ent group, employees and contractors. In addition to the initial training programs for all emergency response team members, annual refresher training is provided along with quarterly drills and exercises.  Emergency response equipment is maintained in prime condition and includes a fully equipped ambulance, hazardous materials response vehicle, two fire trucks and sophisticated rescue apparatus.  The emergency response teams operate under the Incident Command System. All positions in each response team have at least two alternates and all members of the Emergency Management Group have designated and trained alternates.



The PCS Aurora facility coordinates training programs with the local fire and rescue teams. This training includes joint exercises on an annual basis.  The public is notified by using the county communications system.





  Changes to Improve Safety



The facility continues to improve initiatives such as focusing on leading indicators, on-site inspections, corporate assessments, third party assessments, safety leadership coaching, etc. In addition, we are improving our safety performance by focusing on "Our Culture of Care", our Corporate safety strategy. The behaviors that grow this culture are:

    Lead

   o       We are each accountable and model the way.

   o       We speak up and we look out for each other.

   o       We lead at home and in our communities.

    Collaborate

   o       We create an inclusive environment where all are valued and respected.

   o       We listen, collaborate, share information, and support each other.

    Challenge

   o       We celebrate success but are always looking to improve.

   o       We challenge the status quo.

   o       We do it safely or not at all.

    Trust

   o       We understand we make mistakes and gain value from the learnings.

   o       We create an environment where feedback is valued, recognition is frequent, it is safe to speak up, and to stop work when necessary.
